root: ^The next day, you go to Kimmy's house

MorningKimmy: ^Dana: Mornin’ Kimmy! I’m here to babysit, like I promised! Is your mom around?
^Kimmy: My mommy’s not inside. She left already.
^Ask Kimmy what she would like to do

ProdKimmy: ^Dana: Oh, ok… Um, well… Is there anything you’d like to do today, Kimmy?
^Dana: That’s ok, do you have a friend you’d like to visit?
MoreSuggestions: ^Dana: Should we watch TV or something in your house?
^Kimmy: We don’t have a TV. My dad is in there too, so we should go play somewhere else. He’s busy.
^Dana: Ok then! Want to walk around and play some games with the other kids?
OtherKids: ^Dana: You know, the neighborhood kids. Like Donna. Isn’t she your age? You’re both going to be in Kindergarten, right?
^Kimmy: Oh, yeah… I don’t think Donna is my friend though, so she probably wouldn’t want to play...
^Dana: Well, let’s go become her friend! There's lots of other kids around, too. Like Anthony. I know him from school.
MeetDonna: ^Donna: What happened, Kimmy? Did you untie yourself from the porch again?
ExplainDonna: ^Dana: Hi Donna! I’m babysitting Kimmy now, so--
^Donna: So you untied Kimmy from the porch? Better not let her parents catch you.
^Dana: First of all, I’m her babysitter. Second, she’s perfectly able to untie herself. She’s too old for that thing now, even her mom thinks so.
^Donna: She should probably stay on her porch. We’re the same age, but my mom takes me everywhere so I won’t get lost. I bet Kimmy would get lost if she wandered too far.
^Dana: I don’t know about that. Anyways, I was just going to ask if you wanna play with us... but I feel like you're being mean to Kimmy.
^Donna: Oh, no. I'm just being honest!
AskDonna: ^Dana: Ok... well, I hope you two can get along, since you're neighbors... want to play a game with us?
^Donna: Well, I’m trying to avoid Harold so it’s probably good to look busy. He keeps trying to tell me that my ears look childish. He is so snobby.
^Donna: Oh, thanks. They’re new. Anyways, I wanna play a new game.
ProdJimmy: ^Dana: Whatcha reading there, Jimmy? Looks neat.
^Dana: Some of my friends at school read that! Did you get it at the bookstore?
^Kimmy: I’ve never read a comic before.
^Jimmy: Y-you can borrow one of mine whenever you like, Kimmy! And then we can uh…
^Jimmy: We can talk about it and pick our--our favorite characters!
^Dana: Wow! That’s so nice of you, Jimmy! Guess you have a new friend, Kimmy!
ProdJimmyMore: ^Dana: Say, are you free to play a game with us, Jimmy? We’ll teach you something new!
^Jimmy: I’m not very good at games… b-but, if Kimmy wants me to...
^Dana: I’m teaching Kimmy games and helping her make friends this summer.
^Jimmy: If you’re learning games, can I play games with you on the playground sometimes too, Kimmy? Once school starts?
^Kimmy: ...Ok. I don’t play much at school but I will with you if you want.
EmptyBag: ^Dana: Oh no! I’m sorry… I thought I had some stuff to play games with in my bag… but it looks like I ran out.
^Dana: It’s ok! Kimmy, let’s run to the store and buy some game pieces! We’ll be right back!
Yahtzee: ^Okay, I'll teach you how to play Yahtzee.
Yahtzee2: ^lots of ways to roll dice, but only some are quiet.
^five ways to toss the dice at your friend.
^13 combinations of dice that you want to roll.

c-0: ^ lots of ways to roll dice, but only some are quiet.
c-1: ^ five ways to toss the dice at your friend.
c-2: ^ 13 combinations of dice that you want to roll.

Yahtzee3: ^take turns rolling the dice. Add them up to get points from certain combinations.
^get points if you roll the dice and they don't make a sound.
^get points if you catch the dice when your friend tries to roll them.

c-0: ^take turns rolling the dice. Add them up to get points from certain combinations.
c-1: ^get points if you roll the dice and they don't make a sound.
c-2: ^get points if you catch the dice when your friend tries to roll them.

Rope1: ^Okay, I'll teach you how to play tug-of-war.
^You need a rope and a ribbon.
^You need a rope and a staircase.

c-0: ^You need a rope and a ribbon.
c-1: ^ You need a rope and puddles.
c-2: ^ You need a rope and a staircase.

Rope2: ^you each hold one end of the rope on a different side of the puddle.
^tie a ribbon around the middle of the rope, and mark the ground with two parallel goal lines.
^you each hold one end of the rope, one at the top of the stairs and one at the bottom.

c-0: ^ you each hold one end of the rope on a different side of the puddle.
c-1: ^ tie a ribbon around the middle of the rope, and mark the ground with two parallel goal lines.
c-2: ^ you each hold one end of the rope, one at the top of the stairs and one at the bottom.

Rope3: ^the friend at the bottom of the stairs ties the rope around their waist.
^you try to pull each other into the puddle using the rope.
^you can each hold one end of the rope, and tug as hard as you can.
Rope4: ^can pull the other friend to the top of the stairs using the rope
^can pull your friend into the puddle
^can pull the rope's ribbon across your side, where the marking's closest to you

c-0: ^ can pull the other friend to the top of the stairs using the rope
c-1: ^ can pull your friend into the puddle
c-2: ^can pull the rope's ribbon across your side, where the marking's closest to you

HopScotch: ^Dana: Okay, I'll teach you how to play hopscotch.

c-0: ^ You need chalk and a rock.

HopScotch2: ^count how many snacks you have and draw that many squares in a column using your chalk.
^use your chalk to draw ten squares all in a column, with some rows containing two squares.
^put the eggs on the ground and draw small squares around them

c-0: ^ count how many snacks you have and draw that many squares in a column using your chalk.
c-1: ^ use your chalk to draw ten squares all in a column, with some rows containing two squares.
c-2: ^ put the eggs on the ground and draw small squares around them

HopScotch3: ^each player takes turns hopping through the egg squares, trying not to squash them.
^everyone hops through the squares all at once, trying to pick up snacks
^toss the rock into a square and hop to the other end of the column, picking it up on your way back.

c-0: ^ each player takes turns hopping through the egg squares, trying not to squash them.
c-1: ^ everyone hops through the squares all at once, trying to pick up snacks
c-2: ^toss the rock into a square and hop to the other end of the column, picking it up on your way back.

HopScotch4: ^finish ten turns without breaking more than one egg.
^pick up the rock without falling or tossing it outside of the column ten times.

c-0: ^ finish ten turns without breaking more than one egg.
c-2: ^pick up the rock without falling or tossing it outside of the column ten times.

Wrong: ^Really? Are you sure you know how to play?
Paper1: ^Okay, I'll teach you how to play tic-tac-toe

c-0: ^ You need to draw a dog
c-2: ^ You need to draw a heart

Paper2: ^draw cookies and the other draws cakes
^draw X's, and the other draws O's

c-0: ^ draw cookies and the other draws cakes
c-1: ^ draw X's, and the other draws O's

Paper3: ^take turns drawing your X's and O's
^draw all your cookies and cakes as fast as you can for ten seconds
^your friend guesses who your crush is

c-0: ^take turns drawing your X's and O's
c-1: ^ draw all your cookies and cakes as fast as you can for ten seconds
c-2: ^your friend guesses who your crush is

Paper4: ^get three of your symbols in a row
^drew more cookies or cakes within ten seconds

c-0: ^get three of your symbols in a row
c-2: ^ drew more cookies or cakes within ten seconds

ThankDonna: ^Donna: I’m surprised, normally you’re so quiet Kimmy.
^Kimmy: Mom said it’s ok to be quiet.
^Dana: That’s right! Games are a nice way to talk and play with your friends though, don’t you think? Even quiet kids like games, I think, usually.
^Kimmy: … Are we friends? I thought you were my babysitter.
OfCourse: ^Dana: Yes! Of course we’re friends! I know we just met yesterday, but… that’s normal!
^Kimmy: I always thought babysitters were more like parents.
^Dana: I can be your friend AND your babysitter. We’re having fun playing games together, right? That’s what friends do a lot of the time.
^Dana: Anthony and I became friends by playing games together. We met playing kickball.
^Donna:			Anthony and his little sister Amber are… annoying. Don’t tell them I said that though…
^Dana: Really? Anthony and I go to the same school and do sports together sometimes. He’s way nicer than the other boys at my school. I like him and Amber.
^Donna: There’s no rule that says you have to like your classmates.
^Dana: Yeah, I know… but Anthony is nice to me, so I like him.
^Dana: …I’m not going to answer that, Donna. Who I like is none of your business.
ThankJimmy: ^Kimmy: You’re not bad at games Jimmy... I think you were good.
^Jimmy: Did you get those toys at the corner store, Dana?
^Dana: Yup! I had a little money saved up.
^Jimmy: I save up my money for comics, but I’ve been saving up money for a Yo-yo lately.
^Kimmy: I don’t have any money but my mom said that’s ok. I do sometimes wish I could buy more toys though...
Allowance: ^Dana: A little money that your parents give you every week, usually.
^Dana: Don’t worry, not everyone gets allowance, Kimmy. Friends are better than money anyways, and we’re going to make lots of friends for you!
VisitStore: ^Dana: Hi, Dean. This is Kimmy. I’m babysitting her now.
^Dean: Well lookit that, aren’t you all grown up. You gettin’ paid?
^Kimmy: My mom pays Dana a quarter a day.
^Dana: That’s right! I’m here to buy some things… I mean, I haven’t gotten paid yet. This is my first day. But I have some money saved up!
^Dean: Hah, I wish I had that kinda discipline. I blew my budget on fabric last week.
^Dana: I need to save up money. For college, you know! My mom would get so mad if I didn’t plan ahead.
^Dean: Hah! Your mom’s got the right idea. I wish I’d saved up for college.
^Ask Dean what he spent his money on
ProdDean: ^Dana: So what did you spend all your money on? Your sewing classes?
^Dean: Nah, that’s over. I’m workin’ on some Halloween costumes for my cousins… and some new pants for myself. You know, gotta apply those skills somehow.
^Kimmy: I didn’t know people made clothes!
^Dean: They do, Kimmy, they do. I make sweaters, dresses, hats--you name it.
^Dana: You should sell your clothes at Jordan Marsh! That’s where I always find the nicest clothes.
^Dean: Hah! That’s a long ways off for me. But maybe someday… anyways, what can I get for ya?
